There's not enough words to really describe my deep love (and hate, but read on) for this game and I truly believe Oldschool RuneScape is one of the best games of all time. Right now is the absolute BEST time to jump in for the first time, or again after awhile if you've played before - this is the game's platinum age and you can't miss it. Steam charts do NOT grasp the full extent of the hype - 150,000 people play daily.

Here's my HONEST review as a veteran player. (TL;DR at the bottom)

In 2012, the developing company Jagex absolutely fumbled the bag and destroyed the original game (RuneScape/RS3) with a terrible-at-the-time update (too much to get into here), 6 months later in February 2013 after massive community backlash, they re-launched the 2007 version, the ''golden age'' of the game, and It went through a period of hype, quick die-off, long stagnation, and then re-development to create what is the game we all know and love today.

The issues that led to the downfall of the original cannot exist because all major updates outside of balancing require a successful vote via in-game poll system to pass (70%+) and these days the development team is comprised of tenured, veteran employees, and newer, dedicated, ACTUAL PLAYERS who've been through the lows of the past that now get to work on their passion and preserve it.

Every level you achieve, and every item you earn mean something. This isn't like many other MMOs you may have played where every new major content expansion or update completely nullifies previously sought items. Your achievements and effort mean something and will always stay. Your best-in-slot equipment, weapons, and armor do not suddenly become worthless upon an update. They may, rarely, be superseded by a newer item but the old one retains usefulness and value. The game thrives on it's horizontal progression system.

Instead of WASD movement, this game relies on your mouse and clicking the most. You'll still use your keyboard, but usually only your function (F1/F2 etc) keys to change UI tabs significantly faster than clicking the icon. Think of this as a rhythm game, all actions and functions are on a 100bpm/0.6s "tick" system. Focusing on the rhythm itself is ABSOLUTELY NOT ESSENTIAL in the beginning, and is only necessary at a late-game stage where select combat encounters and certain training methods require tick-precise input. By the time you get there, you'll understand. It's incredibly approachable from a know-nothing beginner standpoint, and easy to learn over time because the game will ease you into it.

Some people have a hard time enjoying the game due to the low graphics quality. I don't know what to tell people who are hung up on this. There are certain plugins on playable game clients that can resolve this to an extent - but I've always been a gameplay over graphics person. The low-poly style of OSRS is it's charm. You don't need "nostalgia glasses" to play the game, and I disregard that argument. This isn't supposed to be a modern game with modern frills, and if it's not for you, then it isn't for you - and that's fine.

The gameplay loop of skilling and killing can be rewarding for some, but a slog for others. I won't lie, it can be HARD to get into for new players if you aren't willing to make a commitment, but when you do it is extremely rewarding. The highest level per skill is 99. 50 isn't halfway, haha, no. It's 92 - because the experience curve is EXPONENTIAL. The original developers in 2001 never expected people to make it to 99, nor did they expect people to make a goal of getting 99 in *every* skill. Skills are, however, balanced well and 90% of playable content is unlocked by the time you're 1/4th to 99 (level 85), so maxing skills aren't strictly necessary but more of a long-term goal. For example, I've been playing OSRS since 2013, have significantly more hours off-Steam, and am still only at 2,330 total levels (maxed is 2,376) but enjoy all of the available content.

Finally, I can't speak to every issue the game has but I can speak two of the bigger ones, first, the 'bot' problem - it's not like TF2 if you're curious. 
Like any MMO with an expansive game and active economy, there's people who want to make as much money (in-game, and REAL) as possible. Look up how reliant Venezuela is on OSRS gold. It's a big problem. Jagex is absolutely doing it's best to stop them and solve it, but this is an arms race as old as time, and cannot ever truly be won. I won't fault them fully for the issue, as it's only natural to be had, but they could be doing more.
Second, account security and customer support. For the longest time, Jagex has been notoriously HORRIBLE about keeping good customer support despite being a billion dollar company. They're recently been making public strides to improve this. Personally, I have not had issues. My infosec is good, but it isn't for everyone. Keep your stuff secure.

Most of the loudest voices talk about these two issues and while they are problems, they are not as massive and overblown as some people make them out to be - your mileage may vary.

So, with as much as I've written to be said so far, and without prolonging this review to the point nobody wants to read, I'll summarize with a quick TL;DR.

TL;DR, the game is fun. It's grindy, it takes time, and it has it's quirks - but if it wasn't enjoyable and rewarding it wouldn't be getting as much traction as it does today. Massive community, foundational in early internet culture and maintains a large footprint today. The phrase 'you don't quit, you just take a long break' comes from RS and is absolutely true.

Give it a try.

Old School RuneScape is the only game where you log in “just to do a farm run” and wake up three hours later woodcutting in a completely different part of the world with no memory of how you got there.

It’s:

* 50% nostalgia
* 30% grinding
* 20% staring at XP drops like they’re stock prices

---

### Pros:

* Truly playable on **any** PC. If it can run a web browser and mild shame, it can run OSRS.
* One account, one character, 47 different “build ideas” you will never actually commit to.
* Skills for everything: cooking, fishing, mining, construction, even “standing in a bank wearing fashionscape pretending you’re busy.”
* Quests are simultaneously unhinged and legendary:

  * Help a sheep
  * Kill a dragon
  * Commit light tax fraud for the King
* The Grand Exchange is a fully functional anxiety marketplace where you list an item, forget about it, and then get 12m gp randomly one week later.

### Cons:

* “AFK” content that somehow still eats your entire evening.
* You will absolutely misclick and light a fire in the middle of Varrock bank at some point.
* New players: killing goblins.
  Veterans: clicking on a single pixel in Barbarian Assault for 2 hours.
* Level 99 in anything doesn’t mean “you’re done,” it means “now do it again but more efficiently.”

---

### Peak Old School Moments:

* Spending 15 minutes theorycrafting a money-making method that earns 150k/hour while rocking 300m in the bank.
* Saying “I’ll just do one more Slayer task” and suddenly it’s 3 a.m. and your coffee is cold and your cat hates you.
* Dying in the Wilderness, losing everything, calmly closing the game like “yeah that’s fair.”
* Getting a super rare drop, screaming, then realizing you can’t tell non-players because they won’t understand why a pixel stick made you emotional.

---

10/10

Just started recently after seeing the hype for sailing and it’s been really addicting so far. I’m glad that it runs on mobile so I can do a little whenever I have time and carry that progress back over to steam without having to do anything special on my part. For now I’m staying free to play until I’ve built up some more skills and done the quests available but I can definitely see myself becoming a member in the future. Great if you need a time sink (for quests) or something to just turn your brain off but be working on an objective (for leveling or making money). Only complaint so far is as free to play you’ve got a long hold on your account before you can start trading with people, they can trade you but you can’t trade anything back for a good chunk of in game time.

⭐ 11/10 – Peak 2007 never left

I logged in for nostalgia.

Now it’s 3 AM, I’m clicking on virtual rocks while watching YouTube videos about efficient tree-cutting routes. My fingers have developed muscle memory for “1, 2, 3, drop, repeat.”

I told myself I’d “just do a few quests.” It’s been six months. I’ve fought dragons, joined a cult, and still haven’t gotten 99 Cooking.

Every time I die, I lose 3 hours of progress and somehow thank Jagex for the experience.

The economy is run by people with spreadsheets and gambling addictions. The Grand Exchange is basically Wall Street if everyone wore party hats and argued about cabbage.

Highlights:

Chopped 14,000 logs to afford a hat.

Got scammed by someone named “TrusTMeIRl” — twice.

Accidentally clicked “Follow” instead of “Trade” and ended up in Falador.

Spent 40 minutes trying to find a bank, then remembered I was in the Wilderness.

10/10. The grind never ends, but neither does the trauma bonding.

Let me preface this review by saying that the game is amazing, I have sunk 2400 hours into my main account and almost have a 2000 skill total, two maxed skills, quest cape, I have played this game for 2 years.
The amount of content is amazing, your goals can constantly change while the game gives you freedom to do basically anything you want. The ingenuity of this simplicity has allowed hundreds of special snowflake accounts explore the limits of this game like chunk locked accounts, tileman mode, etc.

However, as it stands I can not recommend this game to any newcomers whatsoever. Jagex has not only dropped the ball, the ball has went through the basement and is in China. Picture this: You get off the tutorial island and start your first quest to kill an imp.. Sorry can't do that, every imp spawn is immediately killed by a scripted account (A bot).
And sure, while that may at first make you feel like this problem only persists for the F2P version of the game, this problem is made a thousand times worse in the members worlds.
Every single activity you can think of, from afk fishing to doing endgame raiding and bosses, it's all botted. The current playercount of around 200k has to be 160k bots, I'm not even inflating this number. Every single activity, every single world. I saw 20 rogue's chest wilderness bots with enough thieving xp to be found on the highscores, and this was just in 2 german worlds.

The problem is: Jagex doesn't care about bots, at all. Their new CEO, the new company they've been bought up by, they see bots as a GOOD thing, since more player count = more customers = more money.. Which is what ultimately ruined this company and by extension both of their games (Oldschool and RS3).
And when the bank you've been building up for 2 years on your account that's been powered by bonds up until this point loses 100 million gold in a week and the bonds go up to 15m.. Yeah no, I quit.
The way they handled this is ultimately pathetic and pointless, announcing a random bingo event instead of even acknowledging let alone banning the bots which kill the 20 year old economy??? Look at any item that could be botted in a price tracker, look how much it has crashed since may this year. Blighted supplies, raw materials, even endgame uniques from hard content like raiding. All due to them not banning gold buyers.

Before a bot apologist comments something akin to "There's been bots ever since day 1" "There's no way to detect them" etc.etc.etc., Jagex has turned their bot detection off by purpose, which has lead to bots outgrowing the actual playerbase within these past few months.
Removed pride event because it's "political"... In a game whose almost every quest is about politics.

Tried to like it, played about 4hrs (switched to the Lite client for notification while skilling) and I just found it dull. The combat, the aesthetic, the interactions... I don't know they were just boring. I've never played before so got no nostalgia for it either.
This game is full of hackers. Jagex is not secure and they do not offer assistance. Do not play this game. It is NOT worth it. 86 up and cannot recommend.
